Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On an unknown date, an unknown adult believed to be one of
Wolverine Center staff inappropriately touched Youth A’s genitals.
It is unknown if this was above clothing or below clothing.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via telephone on 5/20/25. There was
no additional information to share.
Interview held with Chief Administration on 5/21/25 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. CA reported not being
present when the incident occurred but reported speaking with
Staff 1 and reviewing reports related to the incident. CA reported
not being aware of Youth A disclosure of being touched by
someone at the facility. CA denied this information had been
reported to CA.
Supervisor was interviewed on 5/21/25 face to face in
collaboration with MDHHS worker at Wolverine Center.
Supervisor reported Youth A has never expressed concerns about
being touched inappropriately by staff or other residents.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 6/11/25 at Capstone
Academy.
Youth A reported he ran away from the facility because he was
upset and did not want to be there. However, he refused to
discuss any of the other details regarding the investigation.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 7/1/25 at Wolverine
Center. Youth B reported Youth A pulled his pants down to
expose his penis in the past. Youth B reported never seeing a
staff member or peer touch youth inappropriately.
Youth C was interviewed face to face on 7/1/25 at Wolverine
Center. Youth C reported feeling safe at the facility and have
never heard of any staff members being inappropriate with Youth
A. Youth C reported Youth A is known for pulling out his penis.
Youth C stated when this happens, the other youth are separated
from Youth A.
2

Therapist was interviewed face to face on 7/1/25 at Wolverine
Center. Therapist reported the biggest concern for Youth A is his
history of AWOL. Therapist reported Youth A participates in
therapy once a week and has never disclosed any concerns about
being touched or spoken to inappropriately by staff members.
Therapist reported Youth A has a history at the facility for
exposing himself and talking inappropriately to youth. Therapist
also reported that Youth A had a 2:1 staff ratio. Youth A is now
reported to be at the hospital to address his mental health.
Kids Talk held on 5/29/25. MDHHS worker was present for the
Kids Talk. This is a summary of MDHHS notes:
A Kids Talk interview was conducted to address the sexual abuse
allegation. During the interview, Youth A was talking to people
who were not present. Youth A reported a recent incident at
Wolverine, stating he walked out of the facility and encountered a
random person. The individual reportedly told him their name, but
Youth A could not recall it. He stated the person took him directly
home. Youth A reported his mother called the police, which
resulted in him being returned to Wolverine. Youth A was able to
identify his “private parts” as the parts he uses to go to the
bathroom. He denied that anyone has touched him.
Interview held with Foster Care Specialist on 5/22/25. Foster
Care Specialist reported Youth A has behaviors that include acting
out sexually and AWOL. Foster Care Specialist reported Youth A
has not disclosed sexual abuse concerns to him. Foster Care
Specialist also reported having no concerns with Wolverine at this
time and believes the facility is meeting Youth A’s needs.
Documents Reviewed:
Employees Standard of Conduct: Staff must not socialize on a
personal level with present or former client of facilities; Staff must
not have any sexual or intimate contact with present or former
residents of facilities; Staff must not "rough house" or verbally
"horseplay" with clients; and Staff must not give clients gifts
including money, clothing, or food.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance per Kids Talk, staff, and Youth
interviews. Youth A denied he was touched on his genitals. Per
Therapist, Youth A has a history of sexually acting out at the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4124
Section Communication
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a written policy regarding
communication that ensures that a child is able to communicate
with family and friends in a manner appropriate to the child's
functioning and consistent with the child's treatment plan and
security level.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On 5/18/25, parents of Youth A called to obtain a status update on
their son, who had returned from AWOL and were denied the
ability to obtain the update. Parents were told to call the next day.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted on 5/20/25 via telephone.
Complainant reported Youth A’s parents contacted the facility on
5/18/25 and requested to speak with Youth A. The staff member
who answered the phone was rude and it was reported Youth A
would not be able to receive phone calls until 5/19/25.
Interview held with Chief Administration (CA) on 5/21/25 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. CA reported not being
present when the incident occurred but reported speaking with
Staff 1 and reviewing reports about the incident. Youth A’s parents
called in at 11:30pm to inquire about Youth A’s status, however,
CA reported these types of calls are only handled by the Case
Manager and Clinician, which is during regular business hours of
Monday- Friday. CA also reported the parents called after phone
privilege time for the youth. CA reported Wolverine policy for
incoming and outgoing calls is that clinical staff must be present.
No calls or resident information can be given out without referring
the caller to clinical staff. Clinical staff work 8am to 5pm but there
is an after-hours staff on call for emergencies. The night
supervisor would determine if a night call would be referred to
after-hours clinical staff.
Supervisor was interviewed on 5/21/25 face to face in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor reported Youth
A’s parents called at 11:30pm to inquire about Youth A well-being.
Supervisor reported phone calls for youth must be approved and
scheduled by the clinical team first. Supervisor reported calls
received after hours—such as from a parent at 11:30 PM—are
typically deferred to the following day to the clinical team.
4

Supervisor 2 was contacted via telephone on 5/31/25 and
6/11/25 but was unable to be reached.
MDHHS worker interviewed Staff 1 and Staff 2 face to face on
5/29/25. Below is a summary of MDHHS notes. Staff 1 reported
Wolverine policy for incoming and outgoing calls is clinical staff
must be present. No calls or resident information can be given out
without referring the caller to clinical staff. Clinical staff work 8am
to 5pm but there is an after-hours staff on call for emergencies.
The night supervisor would determine as to whether or not a night
call would be referred to after-hours clinical staff.
Therapist was interviewed face to face on 7/1/25. Therapist
reported Youth A’s parents may have called during the midnight
shift. Therapist reported due to confidentiality; the staff member
was not able to disclose any information. It was reported case
managers and therapist facilitate phone calls and youth can make
calls as long as case managers or therapists are present and on
shift.
Documents:
Per Orientation Checklist: Client/Family Visitation:
• All phone calls will be made with the assigned WHS Case
Manager and/or assigned WHS Therapist.
• All in-person visits will be arranged by the assigned Foster
Care Worker, WHS Case Manager and/or WHS Therapist.
• Contacts must be pre-approved by the assigned foster care
worker.
Staff 1- Completed Overall Milieu, AWOL, and incident report
training on 3/18/25, 3/19/25, and 5/17/25. Staff 1 was disciplined
on 4/22/25 for insubornation, violation of company rules, refusal to
complete assigned work, violation of safety rules, and
unsatisfactory work performance. Staff 1 received a 5-day
suspension for failure to report line of sight.
Staff 2- Completed Truancy/AWOL training on 4/16/25, Child
Management Techniques on 3/4/25, and Truancy Prevention/Line
of Sight. Staff 2 was disciplined on 1/21/25 for subordination and
violation of safety rules. She received a written warning for holding
a phone in her hand while holding line of sight.
Analysis The agency was found in compliance with agency resident client
telephone call procedure. Per interviews with CA and Supervisor,
5

Youth A parents called after phone call privilege hours for youth.
Clinical staff was not available to approve the call and Per
interviews with CA and Supervisors, this is needed before a call
could take place. Per interview with therapist, if there are concerns
of breaking confidentiality, midnight staff can not disclose the
status of a Youth at their facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 05/16/2025, Youth A wandered from Wolverine Center,
hitched a ride from someone and arrived unannounced to Youth A
parent residence. Law enforcement was contacted who
transported Youth A back to the facility. The staff did not have an
explanation for how Youth A successfully wandered away from the
facility.
Investigation
Interviews:
Complainant was contacted on 5/20/25 via telephone. There was
no additional information to share.
Interview held with Chief Administration (CA) on 5/21/25 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. CA reported not being
present when the incident occurred but reported speaking with
Staff 1 and reviewing reports about the incident. CA reported staff
members were aware of youth AWOL status and called law
enforcement immediately once youth was out of their line of sight.
Supervisor was interviewed on 5/21/25 face to face in
collaboration with MDHHS worker at Wolverine Center.
Supervisor reported being aware of Youth A AWOL status when it
occurred. Supervisor reported being on schedule when the
incident occurred. Supervisor reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 made
efforts to de-escalate Youth A to prevent AWOL but were not
successful in doing so as Youth A was adamant about leaving the
facility. Supervisor reported Youth A was followed to the
intersection by Staff 1 and Staff 2. Supervisor reported per policy,
6

Wolverine staff are only permitted to escort youth as far as one
block south of the facility. Supervisor reported bystanders and
passing drivers began to intervene by telling Staff 1 and Staff 2 to
get away from Youth A. It was reported one bystander had a stick
in his hand, waving it telling Staff 1 and Staff 2 to leave Youth A
alone. Supervisor reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 initially followed
Youth A in an unmarked vehicle in an attempt to re-engage him,
but Youth A refused to get into the car. Supervisor reported
directing Staff 1 and Staff 2 to return back to the facility once
community members became more involved. Supervisor reported
arriving at the scene and contacting law enforcement immediately
before leaving once Youth A was no longer visible. Supervisor did
not observe Youth A getting into a vehicle with anyone. Supervisor
reported Youth A is monitored all the time and was originally on a
one-to-one staffing ratio but was changed to a one-to-two as of
5/7/25 due to making inappropriate remarks to peers and
exposing himself. During active shifts, he is assigned two staff
members; during overnights, he has one.
MDHHS worker interviewed Staff 1 and Staff 2 face to face on
5/29/25. Below is a summary of MDHHS notes. Staff 1 reported
she was one of Youth A’s assigned one-to-one staff on the day he
eloped. Staff 1 reported being aware when Youth A went AWOL.
Staff 1 reported she and Staff 2 took Youth A to the beach and he
had a good day. Staff 1 reported after returning to the facility,
Youth A walked out. Staff 1 reported she and Staff 2 followed him
beyond the usual corner-to-corner policy due to his age and
cognitive delays. Staff 1 reported community members began
approaching them aggressively, including a man wearing a ski
mask and holding a stick. Staff 1 reported they contacted
Supervisor, who met them on the street and instructed them to
return to the facility for safety reasons.
MDHHS worker interviewed Staff 2. Staff 2 reported he has
worked with Youth A since his placement at Wolverine about one
month ago. Staff 2 reported he has been assigned as one of the
two-to-one staff for Youth A and has developed a good
relationship with him. Staff 2 reported being with Staff 1 on the day
Youth A went AWOL. Staff 2 reported going with Staff 1 and Youth
A to the beach earlier in the day, and Youth A had a good day.
Staff 2 reported Youth A left shortly after returning to the facility.
Staff 2 reported he and Staff 1 followed Youth A in the Wolverine
vehicle, attempting to talk him into coming back. Staff 2 reported
people in the community became involved, yelling at Youth A and
Staff 1. Staff 2 reported one man approached with a stick while
wearing a ski mask. Staff 2 reported he and Staff 1 contacted the
7

Supervisor, who met them at their location in the community. Staff
2 reported both he and Staff 1 were directed by the Supervisor to
return to the facility. Staff 2 reported speaking with Youth A when
he returned and asked what he had done while away. Staff 2
reported Youth A disclosed he had spent time with a homeless
person.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 6/11/25 at Capstone
Academy.
Youth A reported he ran away from the facility because he was
upset and did not want to be there. However, he refused to
discuss any of the other details regarding the investigation.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 7/1/25 at Wolverine
Center. Youth B reported being familiar with Youth A and
reported he goes AWOL often. During the recent incident, Youth B
reported witnessing Staff 1 and another unknown staff member try
to redirect Youth A from going AWOL, but Youth A kept walking.
Therapist was interviewed face to face on 7/1/25. Therapist
reported the biggest concern for Youth A is his history of AWOL.
Says that Youth A had a two to one. She reported that staff have
tried to build rapport and redirect Youth A but it was not successful
or safe. Therapist reported staff are now not allowed to go pass a
certain point when following AWOL youth due to community
threats.
Documentation Received:
Staff 1- Completed Overall Millieu, AWOL, and incident report
training on 3/18/25, 3/19/25, and 5/17/25. Staff 1 was disciplined
on 4/22/25 for insubornation, violation of company rules, refusal to
complete assigned work, violation of safety rules, and
unsatisfactory work performance. Staff 1 received a 5-day
suspension for failure to report line of sight.
Staff 2- Completed Truancy/AWOL training on 4/16/25, Child
Management Techniques on 3/4/25, and Truancy Prevention/Line
of Sight. Staff 2 was disciplined on 1/21/25 for subordination and
violation of safety rules. She received a written warning for holding
a phone in her hand while holding line of sight.
Incident reported dated 5/16/25 and authored by Staff 1 was
consistent with interviews from Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor.
Behavior Support policy: Behavior Support Policy: This policy
provides an overview on how staff members provide immediate
8

emotional and environmental support to clients in crisis so that
stress and the risk for violence are reduced. Staff are to utilize
Non-Violent restrictive interventions that follow the Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPl), Non-Violent Crisis Intervention Model.
Critical incident reports are to completed whenever a CPI
intervention was used. Staff are required to complete a Behavior
Notification whenever an incident or event occurs which is out of
the ordinary and the use of non-violent physical intervention did
not occur. Non-violent physical restrictions are never to be used
as a form of punishment, discipline, ensuring compliance,
demonstrating authority, or retaliation. They are only used to
protect client or others from unanticipated or severely aggressive
behavior that places them at serious threat of violence or injury
if no immediate intervention occurs.
Staff members are to continuously monitor the client to ensure
safety and assess for any harmful health or psychological
reactions. If a client being physically controlled appears to be in
physical distress, immediate notification of the Program Manager
or designee is to occur, and the nonviolent physical intervention
technique is discontinued. Immediate medical evaluation is
required under these circumstances. In the event a client displays
an altered mental status, immediate notification of Program
Manager or designee is to occur and when it is determined to be
safe the non-violent physical intervention technique is
discontinued.
The use and choice of all non-violent physical interventions must
be guided by a number of factors
including the following:
l. The need to ensure the safety of other clients and staff.
2. The size and strength of the client to be restrained.
3. The nature and degree of past violent behavior by the client.
4. Whether or not the client has a weapon.
5. Physical or health conditions other client to be restrained.
6. The client's individual Crisis Management Plan (ICMP).
• Police Report dated 5/16/25 documents Wolverine alert to
Law Enforcement for assistance.
• Truancy Policy: When a truancy occurs, the following
steps will be taken:
1. Staff will make efforts to verbally redirect the truanting
client and will offer the client support and alternatives to
truancy.
9

a. If a non-supervising staff is available, they will walk
with the client and continue to provide verbal support
and redirection encouraging the client not to truant.
b. Staff will not physically intervene with the client on
WHS property other than in accordance with CPI
protocol regarding danger to self or others.
2. Staff supervising the group will immediately call a group
attention to support and maintain the security of the
group.
3. Staff will maintain control of the group and conduct an
immediate head count.
4. Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty when line of sight is lost, no later
than 15 from loss of line of sight (when youth is
determined AWOL).
5. The Youth Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead
Supervisor and Program Management who will provide
oversight for incident management.
6. The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law
enforcement is notified immediately (no more than 5
minutes from when youth is determined AWOL.
2. Staff will report the following information immediately to the
Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on duty;
1. Name(s) of the truant client(s).
2. Approximate time and location of the truancy.
3. The direction of travel the client(s) was/were headed.
4. Whether the client(s) appear(s) to present a danger to
self or others in the community.
5. Circumstances prior to the truancy, risk assessment and
other pertinent safety related information.
3. Truancy Notification: In event a client truants from WHS
property or from a home pass the following notifications
will be made;
1. Program Manager or Director (immediately)
2. Local law enforcement agency (immediately)
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per the interviews with Staff
1, Staff 2, and Youth B reported Youth A was supervised at all
times and staff were aware of his AWOL status and followed their
agency AWOL procedure appropriately.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
10

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
